SEQUENCE.NARRATION: The four of you crowd around the receiver of the dial phone, trying to make sense of the incoming transmission. Amidst the crackling of static, you make out a faint alien voice.

DIALOGUE.SPEECH: Is it just me, or does it sound like music?
Hrmm, ou iv vishouk hdla.
Ershk says she thinks you may be right.

SEQUENCE.NARRATION: Pixel fiddles with the controls of the receiver, trying to clear up the static.

DIALOGUE.SPEECH: It’s no use though. We can’t decipher what they’re trying to say if we can’t hear the message clearly.
So...What now?
Give me a minute, I'll try to figure something out.

SEQUENCE.NARRATION: Seems like there’s nothing much you can do here at the moment. Maybe taking a walk in the alien forest will help you think.

DIALOGUE.SPEECH: O-kay… I was pretty sure those striped bushes weren’t here before. I hope I’m not seeing things, I’ve been thinking there was something funny about the air around here...

SEQUENCE.NARRATION: You gently nudge the furry striped bush-looking thing. You thought you heard a muffled “mmph” sound. But it didn’t move or respond. Maybe you’re starting to hear things too.
Mmm, these bushes are pretty soft. You couldn’t help but stroke them. Nothing happened.
Now that you come to think about it, these bushes feel almost too solid to be bushes. You prod this one harder, just to see if there’s any response.

DIALOGUE.SPEECH: Um...

SEQUENCE.NARRATION: Whatever it is saying, or rather singing, it is evidently angry with you. Maybe you prod it a little too hard.

DIALOGUE.SPEECH: Okay, okay, I’m sorry!

SEQUENCE.NARRATION: Your friends rush over to see what the commotion is about. Ershk tries to say something to soothe the angry striped bush.

DIALOGUE.SPEECH: I think that made it angrier.
Maybe she accidentally sang something vulgar.
We better figure out how to communicate with them quick. It looks really pissed.
Anyone here knows anything about music?
Well as a matter of fact...
Let me guess, you’re something of a musical genius too?
Why yes! I’ve been playing Mozart since I was 3!
I can teach you all the basic theory, it’s not that hard. Then we can try to figure out a way to interpret this language together!
That took you guys long enough!
Oh hey! I can understand it now!

My people and I heard your transmission. We weren’t sure what we’re dealing with so we camouflaged into the forest to observe you before we decided what to do. That is, until you decided to poke me with your grubby little fingers.
It still hurts by the way!
For the tenth time! I’m really really sorry about that. I thought you were a bush!
So you got our message then?
Yeah but we didn’t quite understand it.

We were trying to warn you about an imminent attack on this planet and your species! I don’t know if you are aware of this, but your planet has a large concentration of Source crystals. We intercepted a transmission from an enemy ship who wants to commit genocide and mine all your Source Crystals!
That sounds horrible! But we don’t even know what Source crystals are.

SEQUENCE.NARRATION: Pixel points at the glowing crystal on his staff.

DIALOGUE.SPEECH: That? Why would someone commit genocide just to steal a little staff ornament? We’d gladly give it to them if they’d leave us in peace.
They aren’t suppose to be staff ornaments. These crystals contain a mysterious but potent power called the Source, in its purest form. In the wrong hands, it can be very, very dangerous.
I see. So what do you propose? If such a threat is true, as the Chieftain of this clan, I have the responsibility to protect my people.

Our shuttle crashed on the way here, but we’re sending a transmission back to our mothership. They should be sending help down soon. The Crystal Order will do everything in its power to protect your clan.
In the meantime, let’s hope they get here before our enemies. I may be proficient in Source Defence, but even I am no match for a whole fleet of hostiles.
